image.altText: A mother and father holding their young daughter between them, smiling. They are standing on an apartment balcony.

items.synopsis: Medium- and high-density development in established suburbs is being spruiked as the solution to Australia's housing crisis. But there are still some risks.

title.children: Sean and Jane paid $720,000 for an apartment with no car parks and shared laundry. It was their path out of renting

image.altText: two photos of a filthy bedroom

items.synopsis: The disability royal commission found the abuse and neglect faced by two brothers was sometimes "mistaken for disability-related behaviours". Warning: This story contains content that readers may find distressing.

title.children: ‘Violence, abuse, neglect and deprivation of human rights’: Shocking details from Brisbane’s house of horrors revealed

image.altText: Promo image of a line chart showing housing costs broken down by income.

items.synopsis: Housing costs are at record highs, and we can show you who is bearing the brunt of the crisis.

title.children: Where you sit on this chart determines your level of housing stress

image.altText: a man standing in a garage charging his electric vehicle

items.synopsis: On a sunny spring day, Robin can fully charge both his and his wife's electric vehicles by lunchtime. It could be a big step on the path to net zero.

title.children: Could electric vehicles charge the way to a net zero emissions future?

image.altText: Vanessa Hudson, the incoming Qantas CEO, with model plane in foreground showing Flying Kangaroo

items.synopsis: With Alan Joyce announcing his abrupt departure from Qantas two months ahead of schedule, Vanessa Hudson is now in control of an airline with a reputation problem — and disgruntled customers say it will be tough to win them back.

title.children: New Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson faces an uphill battle to restore the public's faith as Alan Joyce departs

image.altText: Albanese stands speaking to media from a courtyard.

items.synopsis: The PM will use a speech to the ASEAN summit on Wednesday to release the government's South-East Asian Economic Strategy, a blueprint aimed at driving trade and investment north into the region.

title.children: Anthony Albanese starts summit season talking trade ties and regional security, with China in mind

image.altText: A woman with blue shirt and name tag sits looking up at and holding the knee of a woman who sits on a raised bed.

items.synopsis: Australia has one of the world's best healthcare systems. But senior physician Fiona Reilly argues it doesn't always work as well as it should for patients.

title.children: It only takes 11 seconds for a GP to interrupt a patient. A simple shift could change things

image.altText: A man looks on, waving his arms

items.synopsis: Spain's beleaguered football federation sacks the coach of its national women's team, Jorge Vilda, less than three weeks after he oversaw its World Cup triumph in Australia.

title.children: Spain sacks World Cup-winning women's coach as post-tournament chaos continues

image.altText: young girl on bus.

items.synopsis: From war-torn hills and valleys, to the sheep and wheat paddocks of remote Australia, the Karen people are determined to pass down their language and traditions to the next generation.

title.children: Karen refugees keep their culture alive in rural Australia after fleeing war in Myanmar

image.altText: A large concrete police station with a sign saying Mt Isa Police Headquarters.

items.synopsis: A 35-year-old woman is in a critical condition while an 18-year-old recovers in hospital, after a man allegedly stabbed them multiple times at a home in Mount Isa.

title.children: Man charged with attempted murder, rape after double stabbing in outback Queensland

image.altText: premier annastacia palaszczuk at a vigil at night speaking into a microphone, a bright light is shining beside her

items.synopsis: Annastacia Palaszczuk has been a favourite topic of discussion at just about every media event held by Queensland ministers over the past week, despite the Labor premier being more than 15,000 kilometres away on holidays in southern Italy, writes Peter McCutcheon.

title.children: What's fuelling speculation about Annastacia Palaszczuk's leadership?

image.altText: A woman in a grocery isle of fruit and vegetables

items.synopsis: The latest GDP data is expected to show an annual slowdown in the Australian economy because of interest rate hikes.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Economy expected to tread water, Wall Street falls, Australian dollar tumbles

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Senate inquiry will examine the federal government's decision to block Qatar Airways from increasing its flights into major capital cities. The decision is at the heart of a political storm with the government accused of protecting Qantas, with critics saying that allowing more international flights will reduce airfares. Senators voted 32 to 31 to establish an inquiry examining the impacts of the Qatar Airways decision, including the cost of flights. But Treasurer Jim Chalmers has told RN Breakfast that the government has no intention of reviewing the decision, and the "decision was the right one, taken in the usual way." "I think the priority now becomes the aviation green paper, Catherine King, the Minister for Transport, has been working very hard on aviation sector reform. You'll see a green paper before long and then a white paper, I think, next year from memory and that's our focus." Shadow transport minister Brigid McKenzie says the inquiry will examine why the decision was made. "I think it's been clear over the last couple of weeks in particular that Australians have a lot of questions about why this government keeps making decisions that keep airfares high and cancellations and delays in the wrong direction." Meanwhile, it was a dramatic day yesterday with Qantas boss Alan Joyce stepping down early, replaced by Vanessa Hudson who has pledged to put customers first. Here's more from my colleagues Kate Ainsworth and Nassim Khadem.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer says no review of Qatar Airways decision

featuredLink.title: New Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson faces an uphill battle to restore the public's faith as Alan Joyce departs

children.content: A Senate inquiry will examine the federal government's decision to block Qatar Airways from increasing its flights into major capital cities.
The decision is at the heart of a political storm with the government accused of protecting Qantas, with critics saying that allowing more international flights will reduce airfares.
Senators voted 32 to 31 to establish an inquiry examining the impacts of the Qatar Airways decision, including the cost of flights.
But Treasurer Jim Chalmers has told RN Breakfast that the government has no intention of reviewing the decision, and the "decision was the right one, taken in the usual way."

"I think the priority now becomes the aviation green paper, Catherine King, the Minister for Transport, has been working very hard on aviation sector reform. You'll see a green paper before long and then a white paper, I think, next year from memory and that's our focus."
Shadow transport minister Brigid McKenzie says the inquiry will examine why the decision was made.

"I think it's been clear over the last couple of weeks in particular that Australians have a lot of questions about why this government keeps making decisions that keep airfares high and cancellations and delays in the wrong direction."
Meanwhile, it was a dramatic day yesterday with Qantas boss Alan Joyce stepping down early, replaced by Vanessa Hudson who has pledged to put customers first.
Here's more from my colleagues Kate Ainsworth and Nassim Khadem.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog, I'm Sue Lannin. A rise in oil prices has seen US stocks fall overnight on the first trading day of a holiday shortened week. The Dow Jones index fell 0.6 per cent after oil prices increased to the highest since November as Saudi Arabia and Russia extended voluntary production cuts. Bond yields jumped with the yield on the 10 year US Treasury bond rising 0.06 per cent to 4.27 per cent as investors focus on the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates. The Australian share market is expected to open lower this morning. The Australian dollar fell more than 1 per cent overnight to 63.77 US cents after the RBA kept official interest rates on hold for the third month in a row and as the greenback gained to the highest level since March. That's a ten month low. And investors are awaiting the June quarter GDP figures which will be out at 11:30 AEST. They expected to show a further annual economic slow down as interest rate rises work their way through the economy. Economists are predicting the economy expanded by 0.3 per cent over the June quarter, and by 1.8 per cent over the year. Over the first few months of the year, the economy grew by 0.2 per cent and by 2.3 per cent on an annual basis. Join us for all today's markets news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: GDP in focus, US stocks fall

children.content: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets Blog, I'm Sue Lannin.
A rise in oil prices has seen US stocks fall overnight on the first trading day of a holiday shortened week.
The Dow Jones index fell 0.6 per cent after oil prices increased to the highest since November as Saudi Arabia and Russia extended voluntary production cuts.
Bond yields jumped with the yield on the 10 year US Treasury bond rising 0.06 per cent to 4.27 per cent as investors focus on the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates.
The Australian share market is expected to open lower this morning.

The Australian dollar fell more than 1 per cent overnight to 63.77 US cents after the RBA kept official interest rates on hold for the third month in a row and as the greenback gained to the highest level since March.
That's a ten month low.
And investors are awaiting the June quarter GDP figures which will be out at 11:30 AEST.
They expected to show a further annual economic slow down as interest rate rises work their way through the economy.
Economists are predicting the economy expanded by 0.3 per cent over the June quarter, and by 1.8 per cent over the year.
Over the first few months of the year, the economy grew by 0.2 per cent and by 2.3 per cent on an annual basis.
Join us for all today's markets news.

title.children: Hannah is one of thousands of home owners seeing the light as RBA leaves rates on hold again

image.altText: A computer screen showing Chinese company Baidu AI chatbot generating image of cat.

image.altText: Russian conscripts standing in a line saluting.

items.synopsis: Cuba claims to have uncovered a "human trafficking network" that coerced its citizens to fight for Russia in the war in Ukraine.

image.altText: A middle-aged white man in a suit with a yellow tie and glasses yells and points while speaking in parliament.

title.children: Senate inquiry to examine Qatar Airways decision as opposition wins crossbench support

image.altText: Coco Gauff clenches her fist

items.synopsis: Coco Gauff becomes the youngest American to reach the US Open semifinals since Serena Williams in 2001 with a straight-sets win over Jelena Ostapenko , while Novak Djokovic made short work of American Taylor Fritz in straight sets.

image.altText: A pair of hands wearing fingerless gloves using a laptop computer in a dark room.

items.synopsis: A notorious Russian ransomware gang which infiltrated one of Australia's largest law firms has now targeted a string of Victorian businesses, including a pathology company.

title.children: North Queensland rugby league coach charged with 32 child exploitation offences

image.altText: A drone shot of muddy tire tracks throughout a grassy field.

items.synopsis: Rangers in North Queensland have fined a four-wheel drive owner and towing company after their "deep wheel ruts" scared protected wetlands.

title.children: 4WD owner and towing company fined after treating wetlands as 'playground'
